comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
This still does not ensure that there is absolutely no way to confuse Integrated Encryption and Key Encryption.

To ensure that, one could use some fixed string containing spaces (there is no way to generate those in Integrated Encryption mode) as the aad in Key Encryption mode (at most 16 bytes to keep it as a single block).

E.g. "JOSE-HPKE KeyEnc".

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: @ilaril why is setting a fixed AAD necessary for the security of encrypting a content encryption key with an AEAD?

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
If Key Encryption uses empty aad, then attacker can take a Key Encryption recipient and convert it to slightly malformed (in easy to miss way) Integerated Encryption message (with no protected headers) that would successfully decrypt (since if there are no protected headers nor JWE AAD, Integrated Encryption uses empty aad). The decrypted message is junk, but some applications can badly mishandle those.

The way to prevent this is to ensure that no aad value is used by both modes. Since no information needs to put in Key Encryption aad, it can be fixed string that is impossible for Integrated Encryption. Easiest way to do this is to include characters Integrated Encryption never uses (anything outside base64url+full_stop).

(There is already similar issue with `A*GCMKW`, but using those algorithms is a bad idea.)

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> If Key Encryption uses empty aad, then attacker can take a Key Encryption recipient and convert it to slightly malformed (in easy to miss way) Integerated Encryption message (with no protected headers) that would successfully decrypt (since if there are no protected headers nor JWE AAD, Integrated Encryption uses empty aad). The decrypted message is junk, but some applications can badly mishandle those.
> 
> The way to prevent this is to ensure that no aad value is used by both modes. Since no information needs to put in Key Encryption aad, it can be fixed string that is impossible for Integrated Encryption. Easiest way to do this is to include characters Integrated Encryption never uses (anything outside base64url+full_stop).
> 
> (There is already similar issue with `A*GCMKW`, but using those algorithms is a bad idea.)

Integrated encryption mandates protected headers for "alg" and "enc" and it will have to be set to "JOSE-HPKE algorithm" and "int".  Even if Key Encryption uses empty AAD, a recipient operating in Integrated Encryption mode will reject any malformed or absent protected header before reaching the decryption step.

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
However, it seems rather easy for an implementation to have a vulnerability by accidentally omitting that check.

(Compare to bulk encryption being AEAD: That is implemented not as an explicit check, but by only having AEAD ciphers wired. Good luck getting past that.)

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
> However, it seems rather easy for an implementation to have a vulnerability by accidentally omitting that check.

You're now talking about the possibility of problems when people don't implement the specification.  That's always possible, but not in scope for the specification (by definition!).

> (Compare to bulk encryption being AEAD: That is implemented not as an explicit check, but by only having AEAD ciphers wired. Good luck getting past that.)

In fact, only AEAD algorithms are registered at [JSON Web Signature and Encryption Algorithms](https://www.iana.org/assignments/jose/jose.xhtml#web-signature-encryption-algorithms) as `enc` values, and non-AEAD algorithms are not permitted to be registered.  Thus, there are no algorithm identifiers for non-AEAD algorithms.

An implementation would have to knowingly violate the spec *and* create non-standard algorithm identifiers to use non-AEAD algorithms.  If an implementer is going that far out of their way to hurt themselves, there's very little we can do about it, no matter what we say in the spec.

comments.author: selfissued

Yes, @bc-pi, the "info" input in HPKE is "something that would allow for an out-of-band contribution to the KDF".  See the use of the "info" input in https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9180 to understand how this works.

As for it being "unacceptable", that's how HPKE works, so by using HPKE, it's, by definition, acceptable.

The use of "private" information is consistent with the contact KDF used by ECDH-ES which uses SuppPrivInfo (see https://csrc.nist.gov/csrc/media/projects/crypto-publication-review-project/documents/initial-comments/sp800-135r1-initial-public-comments-2023.pdf). 

SuppPrivInfo: An optional subfield, which could be null, that contains additional, mutually
known private information (e.g., a shared secret symmetric key that has been communicated
through a separate channel).

The term "mutually known private information" is the one used in [NIST SP 800-56A](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-56Ar2.pdf) in the definition of the Concat KDF (which it calls "The Single-Step KDF").  Thus, I'm prone to keep it, rather than invent a new term.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
Lets recap the 2 locations where we can extend HPKE:

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9180#name-auxiliary-authenticated-app


> HPKE has two places at which applications can specify auxiliary authenticated information: (1) during context construction via the Setup info parameter, and (2) during Context operations, i.e., with the aad parameter for Open() and Seal(), and the exporter_context parameter for Export(). Application information applicable to multiple operations on a single Context should use the Setup info parameter. This avoids redundantly processing this information for each Context operation. In contrast, application information that varies on a per-message basis should be specified via the Context APIs (Seal(), Open(), or Export()).

...

> Application information applicable to multiple operations on a single Context should use the Setup info parameter.

This is IMO not true of recipient info structure... because the recipient info is used once, to encrypt the aead key to the recipient.

That said, if folks want to use info for each recipient and not use aad for each recipient, its possible there are good security reasons to do this, that are unrelated to how many times you use info.

From what I can tell, the only value of the info parameter for JOSE over what we get from the info parameters used in base HPKE is to separate content encryption keys used with JOSE from other keys... if we want it to also separate keys used for specific AEADs with JOSE, we can accomplish that with string concatenation:

JOSE_HPKE_Recipient_Info = "JOSE_HPKE" + "." + JWE_AEAD_ALG + "." + EXTRA_JOSE_HPKE_RECIPIENT_INFO


I implore the authors to forego any attempts at JSON normalization (both existing that requires external libraries like JCS or proprietary to this draft).

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
Sounds like folks maybe prefer a context structure like what we already use for concatKDF... maybe we can find a way to use the same code to achieve a similar result?

The purpose of these context structures is to bind cross layers, either at the KDF level with info, or at the aead layer, with aad.

Some folks like to mix in application specific context to get separation between cipher-texts or symmetric keys.

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> Sounds like folks maybe prefer a context structure like what we already use for concatKDF... maybe we can find a way to use the same code to achieve a similar result?
> 
> The purpose of these context structures is to bind cross layers, either at the KDF level with info, or at the aead layer, with aad.
> 
> Some folks like to mix in application specific context to get separation between cipher-texts or symmetric keys.

This change is introduced for two reasons:

a) Align with COSE-HPKE 
b) JSON context information to be included in the key derivation. 
    1) The "next_layer_alg" in the Recipient_structure solves two problems: 
         i) derived key material is distinct for the JWE HPKE integrated encryption and key encryption modes (in other words, cryptographically domain-separated). 
         ii) Address the attack discussed in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9709/.  
     For these reasons, the above field is mandatory. 
    2) recipient_protected_header, it includes the JWE Per-Recipient Unprotected Header, but I don't see any security benefit. Including unprotected header attributes in HPKE info provides tamper-detection via decryption failure, but does not authenticate those attributes.

If recipient_protected_header is removed, it would simplify the structure to only serialize strings but the drawback is it deviates from COSE HPKE.

As best I understand it, RFC9709 "Encryption Key Derivation in the Cryptographic Message Syntax (CMS) Using HKDF with SHA-256" is the fix for what was called the "lamps attack", which was never to my knowledge shown to be applicable to JWE. The word "downgrade" only even appears in RFC9709 in the title of an informative reference (which I think is to the pdf of the slides introducing what would become known as the "lamps attack" and is about a downgrade from AEAD to non-AEAD).  Remember that JWE doesn't allow non-AEAD content encryption. 

A reference and statement like this is, at best, confusing or distracting. And, at less than best, it's potentially misleading or alarmist.  

If there's something relevant, then maybe it could be briefly summarized or pointed to more directly? And framed appropriately. 

I don't want to derail this PR because it's a major improvement. But it does need to be fixed.
is there a reason to introduce next_layer_alg here for something that already has a name? like content encryption algorithm https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7516#section-4.1.2

Mutually known private information is *not* defined in {{NIST.SP.800-56Ar3}}. As mentioned in April https://github.com/ietf-wg-jose/draft-ietf-jose-hpke-encrypt/pull/41#discussion_r2060452940 but subsequently ignored. 

Can we please stop erroneously saying that it is?

Even the COSE-HPKE document removed it https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/jose/s2YuuyPEtLooDoy7HuLjkI3jCKU/
I created #78 for this though because I don't want to derail this PR for something preexisting and only somewhat related.
why UTF8(...) for things that are ASCII or implied to be binary in other parts of the doc? ie https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-jose-hpke-encrypt-13.html#section-5-2.10.1

The KDF in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7518#section-4.6.2 leverages [NIST.800-56A](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7518#ref-NIST.800-56A) and the spec uses "SuppPrivInfo". However, the field is set to empty octet sequence. 

The reference is correct but whether the field is required or not is the real question.

I will leave it for now.

Good point, fixed. 

~~~
Recipient_structure = ASCII("JOSE-HPKE rcpt") ||
                      BYTE(255) ||
                      ASCII(next_layer_alg) ||
                      BYTE(255) ||
                      UTF8(recipient_extra_info)
~~~

And fixed text in the "Integrated Encryption" section.
It was using the same field name in COSE-HPKE which is no longer relevant based on the recent discussion, modified it to "content_encryption_alg".

My intent is to capture the general principle: bind the content-encryption algorithm into the key derivation context so that algorithm-substitution  cannot occur.

I have changed the wording to:

“Ensures that the derived key is bound to the selected content encryption algorithm, preventing algorithm-substitution issue (similar in principle to the attack discussed in {{?RFC9709}}).”

The "lamps attack" does not work against JWE.

And I think requirements are secondary here, what really matters is how difficult it would be to use unauthenticated bulk cipher. That seems very hard: Nothing defines how to use non-AEAD bulk cipher (this is in contrast to COSE, where how to use unauthenticated bulk cipher is defined).

I think that recipient_extra_info field should be taken to be byte string and not UTF-8 encoded. Looking at JWE, the JWE AAD is clearly a byte string (JWE does base64url on it before sticking the value to JSON string).
Fixed.

The "enc" is not guaranteed to be in JWE Protected Header since this is Key Encryption. "JOSE Header" seems to be the correct term. Also the wording seems a bit clunky to me, maybe something like (needs further wordsmithing):

"The value of the "enc" (encryption algorithm) header parameter in the JOSE Header. This identifies the content encryption algorithm the HPKE-encrypted key is used for, serving two purposes:"

> The "enc" is not guaranteed to be in JWE Protected Header since this is Key Encryption. "JOSE Header" seems to be the correct term.

I agree.
Yes, fixed.
Agreed, fixed.
Agree that recipient_extra_info should be bytes. But do not agree with or even understand the continued confused and confusing pointing to JWA, NIST800-56a, SuppPrivInfo, etc.

Let's also delete the unnecessary and potentially confusing mention of unrelated headers that are not about Auxiliary Authenticated Application info anyway. 
```suggestion
```
Yes, removed it.

pulls.title: Define JWE Key Management Modes for HPKE
pulls.author: selfissued
pulls.body:
Defines the HPKE Integrated Encryption and HPKE Key Encryption Key Management Modes, as requested by Richard Barnes in his WGLC review and as supported during the IETF 123 JOSE meeting.

Updates the JWE [RFC 7516] Message Encryption and Message Decryption sections to utilize these new Key Management Modes.

Fixes #77 
Fixes #79 
Fixes #42 

Cc: @panva @bc-pi @jogu @kodonog

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body:
The working group request at IETF 123 was to integrate the HPKE encryption and decryption instructions into the full set of JWE encryption and decryption instructions.  That's what this PR does.

For your reviewing pleasure, note that the first commit https://github.com/ietf-wg-jose/draft-ietf-jose-hpke-encrypt/pull/83/commits/2e59c772e634bd6c5bab364a9256fe5fb6b9b7b6 contains the unmodified JWE encryption and decryption instructions from RFC 7516 (after converting the source to Markdown).  That way it's easy to see the deltas to them that adding the HPKE modes introduced.

comments.author: panva
comments.body:
> Perhaps im missing something, but if we are going to take the route of updating RFC 7516 could we then revise the language around the usage of the enc header parameter to say in the case of HPKE integrated encryption this header is not used instead of with the value "int".

Exactly. Instead of fitting into the existing modes, a new properly defined mode can make do without an awkward value like "int" in "enc".

An update to https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7516#section-4.1.2 giving an exemption to "This Header Parameter MUST be present and MUST be understood and processed by implementations." would be needed tho.

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7516#section-9 lists a number of ways to distinguish JWE from JWS, from my experience the first and second are wildly used for that purpose, the latter are not. the last one which then expects "enc" would need massaging/removal.

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
> Perhaps im missing something, but if we are going to take the route of updating RFC 7516 could we then revise the language around the usage of the enc header parameter to say in the case of HPKE integrated encryption this header is not used instead of with the value "int".

That would complicate the implementations a bit. JWE allows putting the "enc" parameter in weird places, so implementations would have to assemble the JOSE Header to determine the mode, as opposed to checking if JWE Protected Header has enc=int and branching to IE case. Enc=int elsewhere is not allowed and not recognizing it is not a problem, as decryption will fail safe.

comments.author: panva
comments.body:
> That would complicate the implementations a bit. JWE allows putting the "enc" parameter in weird places, so implementations would have to assemble the JOSE Header to determine the mode, as opposed to checking if JWE Protected Header has enc=int and branching to IE case. Enc=int elsewhere is not allowed and not recognizing it is not a problem, as decryption will fail safe.

> That would complicate the implementations

I disagree.

A generic implementation must assemble the JOSE Header anyway and in doing so ensuring individual header parameters are disjoint across all headers. In the current version "int" having to be exlusively in a protected header is a check that happens after doing so, not before. In my implementations that is at least. I don't see a complication.

What's the difference between "HPKE Key Encryption" and "Key Encryption"? The processing rules look identical. Furthermore, seems like one place in spec says that JOSE-HPKE alg with enc!=int is Key Encryption, and another says it is HPKE Key Encryption.

@ilaril - In HPKE integrated encryption, it seems the only solution possible is to not set the the HPKE info parameter. The HPKE AAD will have to carry the "Additional Authenticated Data encryption parameter".

I get your point. 

However consider the case were there are 2 recipients and one is RSA and the other a PQ/T hybrid... should the hybrid recipient consider the message confidential after Q day?

Perhaps we can reframe this in terms of known algorithms that are not considered strong enough to secure the CEK?

> I get your point.
> 
> However consider the case were there are 2 recipients and one is RSA and the other a PQ/T hybrid... should the hybrid recipient consider the message confidential after Q day?

I think that message should be decrypted, even after Q day. The included RSA recipient is sender's fault (and may present a critical vulnerability in the sender). Receiver has legitimate reason to remove weak algorithms (e.g, RSA in this case) but that does not come into play as the message can be decrypted without any weak algorithms.

Then the recipients are not authenticated (unless the whole message is signed), so a MITM attacker can hide the weak recipients by dropping those from the message.

IOW, it was sender including the RSA recipient that compromised the message, not receiver decrypting the message with RSA recipient.


This is the opposite of signatures, where it is receiver that is at fault for accepting weak signatures, and thus RSA signatures should not be accepted after Q day (unless the signature algorithm is so bad that it actually compromises the key). Even then, mere presence of weak algorithm is not grounds for rejection (unless it is none, as that gives signature error if implemented properly).

> Perhaps we can reframe this in terms of known algorithms that are not considered strong enough to secure the CEK?

The crypto policy enforcement for encryption is on sender, not receiver. It is critical for security, so counts as critical vulnerability if broken. And what that policy is very much depends on environment and possibly even the message.

pulls.title: Apply design team decisions
pulls.author: selfissued
pulls.body:
This PR will apply the design team decisions from 5-Nov-25 at IETF 124 in Montreal.  Those decisions were to:

- Not use "enc" when performing Integrated Encryption.
- Define one new Key Management Mode for Integrated Encryption.
- Integrate the new mode into the Message Encryption and Message Decryption instructions from RFC 7516 and replace them.
- Utilize distinct algorithm identifiers for the use of HPKE for Integrated Encryption and HPKE for Key Encryption.
- Only use the Recipient_structure when doing Key Encryption and not when doing Integrated Encryption.

Fixes #42 
Fixes #77 
Fixes #79 

Replaces #83 

(The initial commit adds the baseline Message Encryption and Message Decryption instructions without modification (other than conversion from XML to Markdown) so that future commits will make it obvious what the deltas to the instructions in RFC 7516 are.)

Cc: @bc-pi @panva @dwaite @leifj @paulbastian @jogu @kodonog @debcooley

comments.author: panva

@selfissued one missing decision from your bullet point list

```
# Summary of Updates to RFC 7516

This specification updates JSON Web Encryption (JWE) {{RFC7516}} as follows:

- Adds the Integrated Encryption Key Management Mode and
  updates the definition of Key Management Mode ({{terminology}}).

- Updates the "enc" header parameter to be absent when

- Replaces the Message Encryption procedure ({{encryption}}).

- Updates the methods for distinguishing between JWS and JWE objects

```

Using both info and aad simultaneously would violate the API guidance in {{Section 8.1 of I-D.ietf-hpke-hpke}}, which advises against the use of both parameters in single-shot HPKE APIs.

That guidance doesn't preclude an implementer using Setup\<Role> and then ctx\<Role>.Seal() or ctx\<Role>.Open() even for a single JOSE message. I say there's no reason to preclude use of mutually known private information in Integrated Encryption outside of AAD if that's what niche use cases call for.

I do not see where it gets used. The only subsequent steps to use Initialization Vector are 16 and 21, and both work on raw Initialization Vector, not on encoded Initialization Vector.

This looks to be copied from RFC 7516, where encoded Initialization Vector is also computed, but not used anywhere.

The only subsequent step is 21, which does not use these values.

And again, seems to be copied from RFC 7516, where these values are not used for anything.

I prefer referencing stuff as opposed to repeating stuff, as repeating is error-prone. At least this is just copy-paste, which is easy — as opposed to something more complicated.

And this is yet another thing from RFC 7516.

Since other stuff is specific to HPKE , maybe:

The "alg" header parameter MUST be a HPKE JWE algorithm using Integrated Encryption

```suggestion
1.  When Key Wrapping, Key Encryption,
    or Key Agreement with Key Wrapping are employed,
    generate a random CEK value to use for subsequent steps,
    unless one was already generated for a previously
    processed recipient in which case let that be the one used
    for subsequent steps.
```
I understand, see my proposal https://github.com/ietf-wg-jose/draft-ietf-jose-hpke-encrypt/pull/84/files#r2565076018

```suggestion
- An Integrated Encryption algorithm MUST be present in the protected header inside the "alg" header parameter.
```
Actually, I think the original is better.

```suggestion
  If no additional context information is provided, this field MUST be the empty string.
```
Resolving outdated thread.

We must include the "Additional Authenticated Data encryption parameter" value specified in Step 15 of {{encryption}} in the computation or the protected header and AAD value are not protected.  Given that this is Additional Authenticated Data, the HPKE "aad" parameter is the logical place to put it.

That leaves the HPKE "info" parameter for the application to use as it sees fit.  There are multiple potential applications of JOSE HPKE that want this capability.

Ilari, please expand the acronym AADEP and say why it's pertinent.  I can't find it in the HPKE spec or anywhere on the Web, for that matter.  Thanks.

@selfissued this section is for HPKE Key Encryption, so no, we don't use HPKE to protect the JWE AAD, as that is done by JWE's "enc" / AEAD as per usual. In HPKE Key Encryption HPKE only protects the CEK and the cross-layer Recipient_structure.

```suggestion
    generate a random CEK value to use for subsequent steps
    unless one was already generated for a previously
    processed recipient, in which case, let that be the one used
```
@panva's suggestion was merged and addressed the problem.
Yes, the JWE Initialization Vector is used in all serializations.  See Step 21.
This is used in all serializations.  See Step 21.
The latest commit updated the wording in a manner similar to that suggested by Ilari.

AADEP => Additional Authenticated Data encryption parameter

Since encryption procedure is supposed to be in order, that value is only supposed to appear in bulk encryption (step 16 or 17), not in key encryption (step 4).
Yes, but step 21 does "BASE64URL(JWE Initialization Vector)" (for any serialization) instead of using "encoded Initialization Vector". IOW, this step gets re-done in step 21.

Step 21 has "BASE64URL(JWE Ciphertext)", "BASE64URL(JWE Authentication Tag)" and "BASE64URL(JWE AAD)" (for all serializations), not "encoded ciphertext", "encoded Authentication Tag" and "encoded AAD". IOW, these steps get re-done in step 21.

I guess it depends upon what you mean by "used".  The value BASE64URL(JWE Initialization Vector) computed in Step 11 is used in Step 21.  Yes, an implementation of Step 21 could throw away the value computed in Step 11 and recompute it, but that would be inefficient.

In any event, this is all text from RFC 7516.  If you want to suggest improvements to it, you can, but I'd rather leave it alone where it is already correct, which this is.  Let's only change things needed to make HPKE work or to fix actual problems found (such as the problem with repeating Step 2 that Filip fixed).

```suggestion
and the possibility of utilizing future HPKE algorithms, including PQ/T hybrid KEMs.
```

```suggestion
Note that JWE HPKE integrated encryption does not require `Recipient_structure` because the JWE Protected Header and JWE AAD are already provided as HPKE aad, which binds these parameters to the ciphertext.
```

```suggestion
    encrypt M using the using HPKE encryption,
```

```suggestion
    decrypt the JWE Ciphertext using the HPKE decryption,
```

We shouldn't be introducing undefined acronyms.  I am guessing that PQ is post quantum but I have no idea what the T is.

Nothing in this section should be specific to HPKE.  This is general JWE text.  *If* the algorithm is an HPKE algorithm what you say is true, but your proposed text forecloses the possibility of Integrated Encryption algorithms not using HPKE.

```suggestion
and the possibility of utilizing future HPKE algorithms.
```

```suggestion

Note that Integrated Encryption does not use the `Recipient_structure` because the JWE Protected Header and JWE AAD are included in the HPKE aad value, which binds these parameters to the ciphertext.

```
T stands for Traditional, HPKE PQ draft does not use the term "composite" it uses "PQ/T hybrid".

Sure, but messages are encrypted using the shared secret derived from the key exchange, it is not correct to say "JWE Ciphertext" is decryted using the public key. 

we can say:
decrypt the JWE Ciphertext using the shared secret derived from the key exchange algorithm.

It also needs to be fixed for Message encryption.

It is incorrect to say encrypt M using the public key. Alternatively, we can say:
encrypt M using the shared secret derived from the key exchange.

That would be RFC 6919 "MUST (BUT WE KNOW YOU WON'T)", because in practice, many applications will not do it.

HPKE is designed to resist such attacks — otherwise its security considerations would have some major disclaimers.

The only thing with key usage that is potentially unsafe is using the same key for both HPKE and non-HPKE algorithms. And even then, causing actual issues is not trivial. Most problematic thing I can think of is using Ed25519/Ed448 keys for encryption — unfortunately there is a way to make that work.

That would be another RFC 6919 "MUST (BUT WE KNOW YOU WON'T)", because in practice, very few applications are going to do that.

And in practice, one can not even rely on explicit checks working. So HPKE in JWE must be designed to resist any such attacks at cryptographic level. Fortunately, that is the case.
We can still use “MUST” here. HPKE itself includes several normative requirements that the protocol cannot enforce

Implementations can ignore it, but that is also true for similar normative usage requirements present in HPKE, such as not reusing ikm across KEMs or not reusing randomness in KEM operations. These requirements cannot be enforced by the protocol either, yet HPKE still states them normatively because they are essential for security. Our use of “MUST” fits the same model.

Except this requirement is not essential for security and is much more difficult to follow than those HPKE requirements,

I have tried to implement this kind of requirement. It was so much trouble that I just left it out. The other comment about flags applies here too.

Those requirements tend to be easy to implement and important for security. This is neither.

I have tried to implement this kind of requirement, it was so much trouble that I just left it out.

And if I did not know that this is requirement is not necessary, it would be a black flag.
It is an requirement that was discussed and added to the draft in the prior versions of the draft. If it needs to be removed, it needs to be discussed in the WG.
It is an requirement that was discussed and added to the draft in the prior versions of the draft. If it needs to be removed, it needs to be discussed in the WG.

We cannot say
> decrypt the JWE Ciphertext using the shared secret derived from the key exchange algorithm.

in this section because that text is HPKE-specific.  This section is written in a way that allows for future Integrated Encryption algorithms that do not use HPKE - just as there are Key Encryption algorithms that do not use HPKE.

Instead, I removed the misleading text about using public keys (and private keys in the decryption section).

We cannot say
> encrypt M using the shared secret derived from the key exchange.

in this section, because that text is HPKE-specific, and therefore doesn't belong in this section.
Changing this is unrelated to the purpose of this PR.  Feel free to file an independent issue describing a specific requested change and the motivation for it.
Changing this is unrelated to the purpose of this PR.  Feel free to file an independent issue describing a specific requested change and the motivation for it.
Thanks but I don't any update to these sections removing the mention of using public/public keys for encryption/decryption.

```suggestion
abbrev: "Use of HPKE in JWE"
```

This section is incorrect now. I would propose to simply remove it as whole given the use of HPKE parameters for Auxiliary Authenticated Application Information is clearly defined in each of the HPKE Key Management instances.
Agreed.
Was there a particular ask to get the X448 variants? I ask because rarely do I see Curve448 actually supported let alone used. (same question applies to KE algs)

I don't see the point behind this SHOULD requirement. When all recipients use the same "alg", in this case HPKE Key Encryption, then the chosen HPKE CipherSuite is tied to the resulting ciphertext / CEK anyway. It doesn't hurt but also doesn't mean much given it's a SHOULD, and FWIW i would object to a MUST.

```suggestion
* ASCII(content_encryption_alg): Identifies the content encryption algorithm
  with which the HPKE-encrypted Content Encryption Key (CEK) is used.
  Its value MUST be the "enc" (encryption algorithm) header parameter value
  in the JOSE Header.
  This field provides JWE context information to the HPKE key schedule,
  which ensures that the encapsulated secret is bound to the selected content encryption algorithm.
```

```suggestion
This value is used as the HPKE `info` parameter when performing Key Encryption with HPKE.
```
X448 is supported by HPKE, see https://www.iana.org/assignments/hpke/hpke.xhtml
It being defined for use in HPKE is not my point.
Avoiding needless JOSE registrations is.

```suggestion
* ASCII(content_encryption_alg): Identifies the content encryption algorithm
  with which the HPKE-encrypted Content Encryption Key (CEK) is used.
  Its value MUST be the "enc" (encryption algorithm) header parameter value
  in the JOSE Header.
  This field provides JWE context information to the HPKE key schedule,
  which ensures that the encapsulated secret is bound to the selected content encryption algorithm.
```
Both COSE and JOSE HPKE drafts use X448, we need to hear the WG that it can to be removed. Please raise it in WG mailing list.
I will, during the next WGLC. It's not a huge deal. Feel free to resolve this thread.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
```

We can say something like:
When all recipients use the same JWE algorithm to secure the Content Encryption Key, placing the "alg" parameter in the JWE Protected Header avoids unnecessary repetition in the per-recipient headers.
Since this is a) no longer true and b) already included in the respective HPKE Key Management instance definitions
I think that's very much pointless, but still better than a normative pointless SHOULD.

Some other checks that need to be done when decrypting:

* If using Integrated Encryption, verify that the Protected Header contains "alg", and that the JOSE Header does not contain "enc".
* If using Integrated Encryption, Direct Encryption or Direct Key Agreement, verify that there is exactly one recipient.

If either check fails, the whole message is invalid.

> If using Integrated Encryption, verify that the Protected Header contains "alg", and that the JOSE Header does not contain "enc".

This feels like an overreach to have in the general routine. Given that Integrated Encryption says

> The "enc" header parameter MUST NOT be present.
>
> The protected header MUST contain an "alg" value that is

---

> If using Integrated Encryption, Direct Encryption or Direct Key Agreement, verify that there is exactly one recipient.

This has always been implied on the account of there not being able to be more than one ciphertext. Why do we need this now?

What should be done if CEK could be successfully determined for two or more recipients, but those values disagree? Each recipient can produce a CEK, but subsequent steps require a single CEK.

Presumably:

If no processed recipient needs timing attack countermeasures — i.e. is not "RSA1_5" — treat the whole message as malformed. Otherwise, proceed with a random CEK.
If the wrong CEK is somehow obtained, the decryption will fail.  So I don't think we need to say anything specific about this.
@selfissued agreed.

> > If using Integrated Encryption, verify that the Protected Header contains "alg", and that the JOSE Header does not contain "enc".
> 
> This feels like an overreach to have in the general routine. Given that Integrated Encryption says
> 
> > The "enc" header parameter MUST NOT be present.
> > The protected header MUST contain an "alg" value that is

This is to check exactly that requirement.

> > If using Integrated Encryption, Direct Encryption or Direct Key Agreement, verify that there is exactly one recipient.
> 
> This has always been implied on the account of there not being able to be more than one ciphertext. Why do we need this now?

It is still possible to represent such nonsensical JWE. And for Integrated Encryption case, seems like only HPKE-specific parts require a single recipient.
@selfissued this should be applied before resolving.

> This is to check exactly that requirement.

And why would we need to have the same requirement in two different places?

```suggestion
```

A leftover from a previusly applied suggestion.

Should an implementation immediately abort upon detecting CEK conflict? Or should it proceed? If it proceeds, what CEK should it use?

Note that how this is done is important for timing attack mitigations.

I think the safest way would be to keep CEK conflict flag, setting it on any failed "RSA1_5" decryption or if successful decryption results CEK different from previous. Then generate a random CEK and then conditional-overwrite the resulting CEK with that if CEK conflict flag is set.

(For an implementation that does not support "RSA1_5" or similar problems, immediately aborting, using the first CEK, using the last CEK or using random CEK are all fine. I think using the first or last CEK would be the most natural for an implementation.)
The decryption procedure from RFC 7516 already repeats some important checks from other places.

Before writing new text about this into the spec, I'd like to understand how and whether it's even possible to get different CEK values for different recipients.

I'll also note that this is about the general decryption procedure and not about the purpose of this PR, so if we do anything about it, I believe that it should be first discussed in a separate issue.

I agree that these are basic checks in line with other sanity checks already in these procedures.  And these belong as part of this PR, since they are prompted by the introduction of Integrated Encryption.

I agree with @panva that this makes the examples less usable.  Let's not do this at this time.

For what it's worth, there are other formatting things that we probably want to address at some point.  In particular, the tables in Figures 1-3 are formatted as ASCII art rather than real tables.
